author: RICHARD BROOKS
title: MENIFEE: Heritage Lake resident died aboard C-130 in Afghanistan
text:
BY RICHARD BROOKS / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 5, 2015 Updated: 8:58 p.m. A Marine Corps veteran from Menifee was among the 11 people killed in last week’s fiery crash of an Air Force C-130 Hercules transport plane in Afghanistan, Menifee Mayor Scott Mann confirmed.
Heritage Lake resident Chris Ruiz was a civilian contractor, Mann said Monday, Oct. 5.
“All hearts in Menifee go out to the Ruiz family,” said Mann, a 25-year Navy veteran. “The healing process ... will be slow. The whole community is standing by to help where we can.”
The four-engine C-130J Hercules crashed shortly after midnight Thursday at Jalalabad air field, killing six Air Force crew members and five civilian contractors who were the flight’s only passengers, Air Force officials announced soon after the tragedy.
There are about 1,000 coalition forces in eastern Afghanistan, including U.S. and Polish troops, according to NATO. There are up to 35,000 civilian contractors throughout the war-torn nation.
Ruiz was a Marine Corps veteran who leaves behind a wife and three young children, Mann said. The two men had never met, though both live in the same area of Menifee.
The Fresno Bee reported that Ruiz was 29 and is survived by his wife, high school sweetheart Lorelyn, and their three children, two girls, ages 5 and 1, and a 3-year-old son.
“He had a ton of leadership ability, even as a high school kid,” said Rodney Brumit, principal of Lemoore High, where Ruiz graduated in 2004. Lemoore is in the Central Valley, south of Fresno.
The cause of the crash remains under investigation.
The C-130J is the newest model of the Vietnam-era Hercules transport.
The plane hit a ground object as it was ascending, then crashed into a guard tower at the end of the airfield, the Stars and Stripes newspaper reported.
The Taliban claimed they shot down the plane. But the Air Force has said it doesn’t appear that enemy fire was involved.
It’s unclear when Ruiz’s remains will return to Menifee or where services will be held.
“We have had tragedies (involving) other service members in Menifee, and the city ... will be standing by to support the family in any way we can,” said Navy veteran-turned-mayor Mann. “I have lost men under my command, and it’s always tough.”
Lewis Griswold, of the Freno Bee, and The Associated Press contributed to this report.
